title: How to Replace a Camshaft Position Sensor on a 2004 Nissan Maxima

steps.headline: Verify that your car (if it isn't a Nissan Maxima 2004) even has one (or more).
steps.description: The Maxima has 2 of them; the right and the left one. Both are on the right side of the engine. Locate them before you start working on them.

steps.headline: Remove any parts that you need to.
steps.description: If you are replacing the Bank 1 sensor, you will need to take off a couple of hoses to access it.

steps.headline: Using your wrench (socket wrench for the bank 1 sensor) remove the 10mm screw that holds the sensor to the engine.
Pull out the sensor.
steps.description: Pull out the sensor and wiring harness from the area that it is fastened to.

steps.headline: Take the channel locks and carefully, but firmly, press down the mechanism to release the sensor.
steps.description: While the image doesn't show the sensor attached, this was the method used to remove it.

steps.headline: Pull out the sensor.
steps.description: It will be a bit dirty, but you should know that, as an aspiring backyard mechanic.

steps.headline: Perform any maintenance that you need to do.
steps.description: Clean the area up (always a good idea) and use any lubricants that you deem necessary.

steps.headline: Replace the sensor and the screw.
Replace any hoses that you removed.
Start your car.
steps.description: It should start up fine now.

tyn: Bank 1 is closer to the driver and the firewall
Bank 2 is nearer the front of the engine compartment
Magnetic retriever (for if you drop anything)
text: Verify that your car (if it isn't a Nissan Maxima 2004) even has one (or more). The Maxima has 2 of them; the right and the left one. Both are on the right side of the engine. Locate them before you start working on them. Remove any parts that you need to. If you are replacing the Bank 1 sensor, you will need to take off a couple of hoses to access it. Using your wrench (socket wrench for the bank 1 sensor) remove the 10mm screw that holds the sensor to the engine.  Pull out the sensor. Pull out the sensor and wiring harness from the area that it is fastened to. Take the channel locks and carefully, but firmly, press down the mechanism to release the sensor. While the image doesn't show the sensor attached, this was the method used to remove it. Pull out the sensor. It will be a bit dirty, but you should know that, as an aspiring backyard mechanic. Perform any maintenance that you need to do. Clean the area up (always a good idea) and use any lubricants that you deem necessary. Plug in the sensor.  Replace the sensor and the screw.  Replace any hoses that you removed.  Start your car. It should start up fine now.
sentences: Verify that your car (if it isn't a Nissan Maxima 2004) even has one (or more).
The Maxima has 2 of them; the right and the left one.
Both are on the right side of the engine.
Locate them before you start working on them.
Remove any parts that you need to.
If you are replacing the Bank 1 sensor, you will need to take off a couple of hoses to access it.
Using your wrench (socket wrench for the bank 1 sensor) remove the 10mm screw that holds the sensor to the engine.
Pull out the sensor.
Pull out the sensor and wiring harness from the area that it is fastened to.
Take the channel locks and carefully, but firmly, press down the mechanism to release the sensor.
While the image doesn't show the sensor attached, this was the method used to remove it.
Pull out the sensor.
It will be a bit dirty, but you should know that, as an aspiring backyard mechanic.
Perform any maintenance that you need to do.
Clean the area up (always a good idea) and use any lubricants that you deem necessary.
Plug in the sensor.
Replace the sensor and the screw.
Replace any hoses that you removed.
Start your car.
It should start up fine now.
